text: Or you can just install the insider version from the marketplace, that is _much_ easier and you'll get a slightly more stable story, i.e. you won't live on `master`, but on something that gets released slightly less frequently.

elements.text: Or you can just install the insider version from the marketplace, that is
easier and you'll get a slightly more stable story, i.e. you won't live on
, but on something that gets released slightly less frequently.

text: Is it safe to use in (in academic's version of...) production?  Are things constantly breaking or it pretty solid?

elements.text: Is it safe to use in (in academic's version of...) production?  Are things constantly breaking or it pretty solid?

text: I use insiders and I haven seen a problem in ever.

elements.text: I use insiders and I haven seen a problem in ever.

text: We do sometimes push out things on insider where we are not sure whether it really works. If we change something bigger, we always try it out on insider first, and we did have instances where that required some iterations. So I would probably be a bit careful about using it for say teaching, where it might be super annoying if something breaks 15 minutes before your class :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Fair enough.   But sounds like we aren't talking abouta  constant sequence of wasted time for our own work.  Just bad luck and checking slack a couple times a month.  Do you feel the same thing about vscode insiders itself if you don't go down to the dailys?  Pretty stable?

BTW, the new no-python jupyter stuff seems to be working well with julia.  I had an issue, but it was a IJulia/Julia bug.... there is a way to flip on their extensions debugging to see what is happening behind the scenes: <https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/issues/4353#issuecomment-761156148>

text: I don't really have a sense about VS Code Insider, I only occasionally use it, so don't really know how stable or not it is.

elements.text: I don't really have a sense about VS Code Insider, I only occasionally use it, so don't really know how stable or not it is.

text: The only reason I would want it is the new notebook UI.  They are (understandably) conservative in releasing it, so I have no idea if it is 2 years away or 2 months.

elements.text: The only reason I would want it is the new notebook UI.  They are (understandably) conservative in releasing it, so I have no idea if it is 2 years away or 2 months.

text: Yeah, I have to admit I'm surprised how long that is taking... I think more than a year at this point?

elements.text: Yeah, I have to admit I'm surprised how long that is taking... I think more than a year at this point?

text: Then it is probably worthwhile to get syntax highlinght in the "old" notebook interface.

text: I think that when <@U6BNE7LTZ> found the syntax highlihght working with julia without directly adding julia to vscode, it relied on the insiders and new notebook UI.
